messages: HIV stands for human immunodeficiency virus.
AIDS stands for acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.
HIV attacks the body's immune system, making it harder to fight off infections.
There is no cure for HIV, but it can be managed with medication.
People with HIV can live long and healthy lives with proper treatment.
HIV is spread through blood, semen, vaginal fluids, and breast milk.
Using protection can greatly reduce the risk of HIV transmission during relation.
Sharing needles or other injection equipment can also spread HIV.
HIV can be transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding.
Testing for HIV is important for early detection and treatment.
Many people with HIV have no symptoms, so testing is important for prevention and treatment.
Stigma and discrimination against people living with HIV/AIDS can make it harder to get tested and treated.
HIV/AIDS disproportionately affects marginalized communities, including people of color and LGBTQ+ people.
Access to healthcare, including HIV testing and treatment, is a human right.
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a medication that can greatly reduce the risk of getting HIV.
Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a medication that can prevent HIV infection after exposure, such as after a needle stick injury.
Treatment as prevention (TasP) is a strategy that uses HIV medication to prevent the spread of the virus.
HIV criminalization laws, which criminalize the transmission of HIV, can perpetuate stigma and discrimination against people living with HIV/AIDS.
HIV/AIDS activism has been instrumental in raising awareness and advocating for the rights of people living with HIV/AIDS.
The fight against HIV/AIDS is ongoing, and everyone has a role to play in preventing transmission and advocating for the rights of people living with HIV/AIDS.
